00032 // Google Test filepath utilities
00033 //
00034 // This header file declares classes and functions used internally by
00035 // Google Test.  They are subject to change without notice.
00036 //
00037 // This file is #included in testing/base/internal/gtest-internal.h
00038 // Do not include this header file separately!
00039 
00040 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_FILEPATH_H_
00041 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_FILEPATH_H_
00042 
00043 #include <gtest/internal/gtest-string.h>
00044 
00045 namespace testing {
00046 namespace internal {
00047 
00048 // FilePath - a class for file and directory pathname manipulation which
00049 // handles platform-specific conventions (like the pathname separator).
00050 // Used for helper functions for naming files in a directory for xml output.
00051 // Except for Set methods, all methods are const or static, which provides an
00052 // "immutable value object" -- useful for peace of mind.
00053 // A FilePath with a value ending in a path separator ("like/this/") represents
00054 // a directory, otherwise it is assumed to represent a file. In either case,
00055 // it may or may not represent an actual file or directory in the file system.
00056 // Names are NOT checked for syntax correctness -- no checking for illegal
00057 // characters, malformed paths, etc.
00058 
00059 class FilePath {
00060  public:
00061   FilePath() : pathname_("") { }
00062   FilePath(const FilePath& rhs) : pathname_(rhs.pathname_) { }
00063 
00064   explicit FilePath(const char* pathname) : pathname_(pathname) {
00065     Normalize();
00066   }
00067 
00068   explicit FilePath(const String& pathname) : pathname_(pathname) {
00069     Normalize();
00070   }
00071 
00072   FilePath& operator=(const FilePath& rhs) {
00073     Set(rhs);
00074     return *this;
00075   }
00076 
00077   void Set(const FilePath& rhs) {
00078     pathname_ = rhs.pathname_;
00079   }
00080 
00081   String ToString() const { return pathname_; }
00082   const char* c_str() const { return pathname_.c_str(); }
00083 
00084   // Returns the current working directory, or "" if unsuccessful.
00085   static FilePath GetCurrentDir();
00086 
00087   // Given directory = "dir", base_name = "test", number = 0,
00088   // extension = "xml", returns "dir/test.xml". If number is greater
00089   // than zero (e.g., 12), returns "dir/test_12.xml".
00090   // On Windows platform, uses \ as the separator rather than /.
00091   static FilePath MakeFileName(const FilePath& directory,
00092                                const FilePath& base_name,
00093                                int number,
00094                                const char* extension);
00095 
00096   // Returns a pathname for a file that does not currently exist. The pathname
00097   // will be directory/base_name.extension or
00098   // directory/base_name_<number>.extension if directory/base_name.extension
00099   // already exists. The number will be incremented until a pathname is found
00100   // that does not already exist.
00101   // Examples: 'dir/foo_test.xml' or 'dir/foo_test_1.xml'.
00102   // There could be a race condition if two or more processes are calling this
00103   // function at the same time -- they could both pick the same filename.
00104   static FilePath GenerateUniqueFileName(const FilePath& directory,
00105                                          const FilePath& base_name,
00106                                          const char* extension);
00107 
00108   // Returns true iff the path is NULL or "".
00109   bool IsEmpty() const { return c_str() == NULL || *c_str() == '\0'; }
00110 
00111   // If input name has a trailing separator character, removes it and returns
00112   // the name, otherwise return the name string unmodified.
00113   // On Windows platform, uses \ as the separator, other platforms use /.
00114   FilePath RemoveTrailingPathSeparator() const;
00115 
00116   // Returns a copy of the FilePath with the directory part removed.
00117   // Example: FilePath("path/to/file").RemoveDirectoryName() returns
00118   // FilePath("file"). If there is no directory part ("just_a_file"), it returns
00119   // the FilePath unmodified. If there is no file part ("just_a_dir/") it
00120   // returns an empty FilePath ("").
00121   // On Windows platform, '\' is the path separator, otherwise it is '/'.
00122   FilePath RemoveDirectoryName() const;
00123 
00124   // RemoveFileName returns the directory path with the filename removed.
00125   // Example: FilePath("path/to/file").RemoveFileName() returns "path/to/".
00126   // If the FilePath is "a_file" or "/a_file", RemoveFileName returns
00127   // FilePath("./") or, on Windows, FilePath(".\\"). If the filepath does
00128   // not have a file, like "just/a/dir/", it returns the FilePath unmodified.
00129   // On Windows platform, '\' is the path separator, otherwise it is '/'.
00130   FilePath RemoveFileName() const;
00131 
00132   // Returns a copy of the FilePath with the case-insensitive extension removed.
00133   // Example: FilePath("dir/file.exe").RemoveExtension("EXE") returns
00134   // FilePath("dir/file"). If a case-insensitive extension is not
00135   // found, returns a copy of the original FilePath.
00136   FilePath RemoveExtension(const char* extension) const;
00137 
00138   // Creates directories so that path exists. Returns true if successful or if
00139   // the directories already exist; returns false if unable to create
00140   // directories for any reason. Will also return false if the FilePath does
00141   // not represent a directory (that is, it doesn't end with a path separator).
00142   bool CreateDirectoriesRecursively() const;
00143 
00144   // Create the directory so that path exists. Returns true if successful or
00145   // if the directory already exists; returns false if unable to create the
00146   // directory for any reason, including if the parent directory does not
00147   // exist. Not named "CreateDirectory" because that's a macro on Windows.
00148   bool CreateFolder() const;
00149 
00150   // Returns true if FilePath describes something in the file-system,
00151   // either a file, directory, or whatever, and that something exists.
00152   bool FileOrDirectoryExists() const;
00153 
00154   // Returns true if pathname describes a directory in the file-system
00155   // that exists.
00156   bool DirectoryExists() const;
00157 
00158   // Returns true if FilePath ends with a path separator, which indicates that
00159   // it is intended to represent a directory. Returns false otherwise.
00160   // This does NOT check that a directory (or file) actually exists.
00161   bool IsDirectory() const;
00162 
00163   // Returns true if pathname describes a root directory. (Windows has one
00164   // root directory per disk drive.)
00165   bool IsRootDirectory() const;
00166 
00167  private:
00168   // Replaces multiple consecutive separators with a single separator.
00169   // For example, "bar///foo" becomes "bar/foo". Does not eliminate other
00170   // redundancies that might be in a pathname involving "." or "..".
00171   //
00172   // A pathname with multiple consecutive separators may occur either through
00173   // user error or as a result of some scripts or APIs that generate a pathname
00174   // with a trailing separator. On other platforms the same API or script
00175   // may NOT generate a pathname with a trailing "/". Then elsewhere that
00176   // pathname may have another "/" and pathname components added to it,
00177   // without checking for the separator already being there.
00178   // The script language and operating system may allow paths like "foo//bar"
00179   // but some of the functions in FilePath will not handle that correctly. In
00180   // particular, RemoveTrailingPathSeparator() only removes one separator, and
00181   // it is called in CreateDirectoriesRecursively() assuming that it will change
00182   // a pathname from directory syntax (trailing separator) to filename syntax.
00183 
00184   void Normalize();
00185 
00186   String pathname_;
00187 };  // class FilePath
00188 
00189 }  // namespace internal
00190 }  // namespace testing
00191 
00192 #endif  // GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_FILEPATH_H_
